body.p:
With the help of God—Wednesday, 15 Shevat
1865, Savannah—

Peace, blessings, and good fortune to
God's friend and my own, the doer of
righteousness, his honor, our teacher and
rabbi Isaac Hzik, may his light burn brightly.

Your letter of the 27th of Tebeth is at
hand, came into my hands, and I rejoiced
greatly. As to Madam Goldschmid, I be-
lieve that if you were as well acquainted
with her character as I, you would never
have sent her a Bible. I marvel that
she returned the same to you. Nevertheless,
in order to do his bidding I went to her
home, and this is what she said. She wanted
a small Bible with in large type, but inexpensive
and then, I believe, not to pay for it.

As to the man whose name is Bick,
that in Polish "ox", is like his name
a goring ox. I have not spoken to him
in many months, and he is now more
peaceful. During the past month of Ab, when he

left for the north, he told me that he would
purchase for himself a Bible when in your
town. He returned home and brought these
two. He told me that the one for $12 are is to be sent to Mr. Dessauer in Macon for
a man whose name is Kraun. I sent
them to Mr. Krau himself, and when I was
there Mr. Krau told me that he had not
ordered any. Nevertheless he kept them
and will pay $12 to Mr. Dessauer. Should
this not prove to be the case, let me know
and I will collect it. (The last three
ordered I have received). As to the second
copy it is in the possession of the Ox. I
could have sold it long ago. I sent my his
brother to him that he should return the
Bible. But he replied that if you wrote
to him to hand the Bible over to me, he would
do so. I would advise you to write to
his brother whose name is Levy E. Bick.
For if you wrote to him directly, I believe
I should never hear of it. Or, write to
me directly. 15 Shevat 1865

I have nothing more that is new;
except that last Tuesday I sent five
hundred dollars to the people of Jerusalem.
The money I sent them on last Rosh
Hodesh Ellul did not get to them till
Rosh Hodesh Heshvan. Certainly this
money just sent will reach them by
Passover, and they will enjoy the holiday.
From his your friend and servant who
is ready to serve him you at all times

I delivered your letter to Mr. Eckman.
He thereupon wanted that I should take in
my care your books now lying in his store.
I said that if you commissioned me to do,
I would do it with the greatest pleasure.
This week he told me that he had some money
to send you, and that he would send it to you
this week. Mr. Einstein went to New York
this week. You will probably see him in
your city. 15 Sheval 1865 The above ?
